frontmatter.title: Introduction and Motivation for PDE-Constrained Optimal Control

children.value:
This lecture introduces optimal control as an optimization problem constrained by equations.
We first build the finite-dimensional analogy, then move to PDE-constrained models.

children.value: solve the state equation repeatedly inside optimization
In optimal control, the PDE is a constraint, not the objective.

children.value:
is the control-to-state operator.
Then define

children.html: f(u):=J(S(u),u),f(u):=J(S(u),u),f(u):=J(S(u),u),
min⁡u∈Uadf(u).\min_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{\mathrm{ad}}} f(u).u∈Uad​min​f(u).

children.value: This reduces a finite-dimensional control problem to a standard finite-dimensional optimization problem.
A standard existence result for the reduced problem:

children.html: fff

children.value: is lower semicontinuous and bounded from below,

children.html: Lt:={u∈Uad:f(u)≤t}L_t:=\{u\in\mathcal{U}_{\mathrm{ad}}:f(u)\le t\}Lt​:={u∈Uad​:f(u)≤t}

children.value: Reason: in finite dimensions, closed and bounded sets are compact (Weierstrass theorem).

In infinite-dimensional spaces, closed and bounded sets are generally not compact.
This is one of the main analytical difficulties for PDE-constrained optimization.

children.value: For PDE-constrained control, state/control live in function spaces (typically Hilbert spaces):
